knowledge_graph.title: Hops
knowledge_graph.description: Hops are the flowers of the hop plant Humulus lupulus, a member of the Cannabaceae family of flowering plants. They are used primarily as a bittering, flavouring, and stability agent in beer, to which, in addition to bitterness, they impart floral, fruity, or citrus flavours and aromas.

inline_images.title: What Are Hops? Everything You Need To Know | Sierra Nevada ...
What Are Hops? A Beginner's Guide | Wine Enthusiast
Growing Hops at Home: An Act of Tradition - Age Old

related_questions.question: What are hops used for?
related_questions.snippet: Hops are a crucial ingredient in the brewing process and are responsible for the distinct bitter flavour and aroma of beer. However, hops have uses beyond the world of brewing. In fact, this versatile plant can be found in a surprising range of products, from food and drink to herbal remedies and skincare.
related_questions.title: Are hops used in anything other than beer? Find Out Now!

related_questions.question: How do hops affect the body?
related_questions.snippet: It has been attributed anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties, as well as diuretic, digestive, sedative, progestogenic properties, even being considered a cure for insomnia. For this wide range of health benefits, it was regarded as a life prolonging plant [3].
related_questions.title: Antioxidants in Hops: Bioavailability, Health Effects and Perspectives for ...

related_questions.question: Why are hops added to beer?
related_questions.snippet: Hops help to keep beer fresher, longer; help beer retain its head of foam—a key component of a beer's aroma and flavor; and, of course, add “hoppy” aroma, flavor, and bitterness. Hops belong to the Cannabinaceae family, which also happens to include Cannabis (hemp and marijuana).
related_questions.title: Beer Fundamentals - What are hops? - Allagash Brewing Company

related_questions.question: What are hops in IPA?
related_questions.snippet: They're a climbing perennial, and tucked inside each cone are tiny yellow pods called lupulin which contain resin and essential oils — the driving source of bitterness, aroma, and flavor in all of your favorite beers. And craft brewers especially love lupulin to pack flavor into IPAs.

buttons.subtitle: What Do Hops Taste Like
buttons.title: What Does a "Hoppy Beer" Taste Like? - Lowercase Brewing
buttons.snippet: New varieties of hops are always being developed, so the kaleidoscope of flavors they can offer continues to grow and expand. However, as a rule, hops add bitter flavors to beer along with a whole spectrum of aromatic notes that can range from woody, spicy, and earthy to floral, citrus, and fruity.
snippet_highlighted_words: bitter flavors to beer along with a whole spectrum of aromatic notes that can range from woody, spicy, and earthy to floral, citrus, and fruity

buttons.subtitle: What Do Hops Do To Beer
buttons.title: Beer Fundamentals - What are hops? - Allagash Brewing Company
buttons.snippet: Hops help to keep beer fresher, longer; help beer retain its head of foam—a key component of a beer's aroma and flavor; and, of course, add “hoppy” aroma, flavor, and bitterness. Hops belong to the Cannabinaceae family, which also happens to include Cannabis (hemp and marijuana).
snippet_highlighted_words: help to keep beer fresher, longer; help beer retain its head of foam—a key component of a beer's aroma and flavor; and, of course, add “hoppy” aroma, flavor, and bitterness

buttons.subtitle: What Is The Nutrition Of Hops
buttons.title: Health Benefits of Hops: Are They Good for You?
buttons.snippet: What nutrients are found in hops? While not typically consumed for their nutritional value, hops contain a range of compounds including essential oils, bitter acids such as humulone and lupulone, and flavonoids like xanthohumol and 8-prenylnaringenin.
snippet_highlighted_words: essential oils, bitter acids such as humulone and lupulone, and flavonoids like xanthohumol and 8-prenylnaringenin

buttons.subtitle: How To Eat Hops
buttons.title: Can You Eat Hops? Explore the Edible Benefits & Uses
buttons.snippet: The most popular culinary use of hops is in the form of hop-infused oils or vinegars. These can be used in dressings, marinades, and sauces to add a distinct hoppy flavour. Hops can also be used to make tea or added to stews, soups, and casseroles for a unique depth of flavour.

buttons.subtitle: Hops Allergies
buttons.title: Hops Allergy: Etiology, Presentation & Management - Los Angeles Allergist
buttons.snippet: Common allergic reactions include skin manifestations like itching, erythema, and urticaria upon contact with hops or hops-containing products. Inhalation of hop dust during brewing or consumption of products containing hops can lead to respiratory symptoms, such as rhinitis, conjunctivitis, and asthma exacerbation.
snippet_highlighted_words: Common allergic reactions include skin manifestations like itching, erythema, and urticaria upon contact with hops or hops-containing products

buttons.subtitle: How To Plant Hops
buttons.title: Hops: Planting, Growing, and Pruning Hops
list: Commercial hops are propagated via root cuttings or rhizomes, not from seeds. ...
In the home garden, hops are best planted in hills. ...
Plant two rhizomes per hill with the buds pointing up and the roots of the rhizome down.
Dig a hole that's about twice as wide as the pot and as deep.
